sections.title: Dental hygiene appointments
sections.body:
Dental hygiene appointments are about maintaining stability, not just polishing teeth.

In practice, they play a central role in keeping gums healthy, supporting the teeth over time, and preventing small issues from becoming larger ones. A hygiene visit isn’t cosmetic maintenance — it’s clinical care focused on reducing risk and keeping things stable.

Regular hygiene care, combined with good daily habits, is one of the most reliable ways to protect your teeth and gums in the long term.
bullets: Gentle scaling and polishing with gum health checks
Tailored advice for brushing, interdental cleaning, and sensitivity
Clear intervals so you know when to return and why

sections.eyebrow: What happens in a hygiene visit
sections.title: What happens at a hygiene appointment
sections.body:
A hygiene appointment involves careful cleaning around the teeth and gums, focusing on areas that are difficult to manage with brushing alone.

We remove plaque and hardened deposits, particularly below the gum line where inflammation tends to develop. Attention is given to areas that show repeated build-up, as patterns matter more than isolated findings.

Time is also spent discussing techniques, habits, or recurring problem areas, so daily cleaning is more effective between visits.
bullets: Gum measurements and bleeding checks where indicated
Targeted scaling to remove plaque and tartar above and below the gumline
Polishing and advice on home care tools that suit your mouth

sections.title: Patients who benefit most from regular hygiene
items: People noticing bleeding gums, tenderness, or bad breath
Patients with implants, crowns, or bridges who need careful maintenance
Anyone prone to staining from tea, coffee, or smoking
Those managing dry mouth, orthodontic appliances, or dexterity challenges

sections.title: A clear, paced visit
items: Discussion of concerns and areas you want us to focus on
Gum health review and plaque assessment
Gentle scaling above and below the gumline
Polishing or airflow-style stain removal where suitable
Home care coaching on brushing, interdental cleaning, and sensitivity
Agreed recall interval based on your gum risk and history
sections.strapline: We keep things unhurried so you can stay comfortable and ask questions.

sections.title: Why hygiene matters
sections.body:
Most gum problems don’t start suddenly. They build quietly over time.

Hygiene care helps interrupt that process by keeping inflammation down and allowing the gums to stay stable. When this is done consistently, it reduces the likelihood of gum disease progressing and helps protect the bone that supports the teeth.

It’s a practical, preventative approach that supports almost everything else we do in dentistry.

sections.title: What to expect after your appointment
items: Mild sensitivity can happen and usually settles within a day or two
Gums may look healthier quickly as inflammation settles
Avoid strong staining foods or drinks for the rest of the day if we polish
Follow the home care plan so results last longer

faqs.question: Does hygiene treatment hurt?
faqs.answer: Most hygiene appointments are comfortable, but it depends on what we need to clean and how inflamed the gums are at the time. If areas are tender, we can slow down, use numbing where appropriate, and focus on making it manageable — not heroic.

faqs.question: Is a hygiene appointment “just a clean”?
faqs.answer: It’s a professional clean, yes — but the purpose is clinical. The goal is to reduce inflammation and risk around the gums, and to keep things stable long-term, not simply to make teeth look shiny.

faqs.question: How long does a hygiene appointment take?
faqs.answer: It depends on what needs doing and whether it’s routine maintenance or a heavier clean. We’ll tell you what we recommend and why, so you know what to expect before we start.

faqs.question: How often should I book a hygiene appointment?
faqs.answer: There isn’t one perfect interval for everyone. We base it on your gum history, build-up patterns, medical factors, and how stable things look over time — and we’ll adjust it if your mouth changes.

sections.title: How often should I attend?
sections.body:
How often you need hygiene appointments depends on your individual risk rather than a fixed schedule.

Some people maintain stability with infrequent visits, while others benefit from closer monitoring due to gum history, medical factors, or patterns of plaque build-up. What matters is responding to how your mouth behaves over time.

We recommend intervals based on what we see clinically, and adjust them if things change.
bullets: Often paired with Routine check-ups (/treatments/preventative-and-general-dentistry) for a full oral health review.
Helpful before or after gum care reviews (/treatments/periodontal-gum-care) when inflammation needs ongoing control.
Supports long-term maintenance for implants and restorations (/treatments/implants-aftercare).
If you’re nervous, we can pace visits and discuss support (/treatments/nervous-patients).

sections.title: Book a calm dental hygiene appointment
sections.body: Tell us about sensitivity or anxiety and we’ll tailor the pace. We can combine hygiene with a routine check-up if that helps.
